title: is a stimulating interpretation of ancient Greek culture as a whole

note: See also a more recent translation by Stanley Lombardo, Homer: Iliad (Indianapolis/
title: The Rhetoric of Manhood
is an excellent study of attitudes toward masculinity in Athenian oratory. The best contemporary English translations of Homer’s Iliad are Robert Fagles, Homer: The Iliad
The Iliad of Homer

note: Mark Edwards, Homer: Poet of the Iliad
title: a more radically contemporary version with an excellent introduction by Sheila Murnaghan. The best contemporary English translation of The Epic of Gilgamesh is by Maureen Gallery Kovacs, The Epic of Gilgamesh
Good general discussions of Homeric epic can be found in Seth Schein, The Mortal Hero: An Introduction to Homer’s Iliad

note: on Life and Death (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1980) is
title: and Charles Beye, Ancient Epic Poetry
On the Iliad in particular
Owen’s interpretative reading, The Story of the Iliad
is still the best introduction to the story
Homeric Hymn to Demeter: Translation, Commentary, and Interpretive Essays

note: see Barry Strauss, Fathers and Sons in
title: The best source for childhood in Athens is Mark Golden, Children and Childhood in Classical Athens
On the relationship of fathers and sons
Stephen Tracy, The Story of the Odyssey
is a full and helpful interpretation of the Odyssey. The best English translations of the Odyssey are Robert Fagles, Homer: The Odyssey
Richmond Lattimore, The Odyssey of Homer

container-title: For an introduction to Sophocles, see Ruth Scodel Sophocles
David Grene’s English translation of Sophocles’s Philoctetes, in David Grene and Richmond Lattimore, The Complete Greek Tragedies: Sophocles II
note: is excellent. See also Carl Phillips, Sophocles’ Philoctetes
title: all with excellent introductions on the poem. For an insightful and stimulating reading of the Homeric Hymn to Hermes, see Lewis Hyde, Trickster Makes This World
Women on the Edge: Four Plays by Euripides
has an excellent section on the staging of dramas in Athens
and Cedric Whitman, Sophocles
a more recent version with an thoughtful introduction by Diskin Clay
Aeschylus
is a fine general introduction to Aeschylus. The best English translations of the Oresteia trilogy are Robert Fagles, Aeschylus: The Oresteia

note: and Blondell, Gamel, Rabinowitz, and Zweig, Women on the Edge
title: Aeschylus: The Oresteia
Both have helpful introductions on the plays. On Euripides’s Medea, see William Allan, Euripides: Medea
Emily McDermott, Euripides’ Medea: The Incarnation of Disorder

note: The latter has excellent introductory material on the background for Athenian drama in general and Euripidean drama in particular. Further Reading 161
title: For English translations of Medea, see Rex Warner’s version in David Grene and Richmond Lattimore, The Complete Greek Tragedies: Euripides I

note: See also Jon Mikalson Ancient Greek Religion
title: The Greeks and Their Gods
is a good survey of Greek religion

container-title: David Grene and Richmond Lattimore The Complete Greek Tragedies: Euripides V
note: with a provocative introduction. On Euripides’s drama, see Douglas Conacher, Euripidean Drama; Myth, Theme and Structure
title: The best translation of Sophocles’s Oedipus Rex is in Robert Fagles, Sophocles: The Three Theban Plays
with an excellent introduction by Bernard Knox. For a brilliant and powerfully-written study of Oedipus Rex, see Bernard Knox, Oedipus at Thebes: Sophocles’ Tragic Hero and His Time
On Oedipus Rex as an exploration of a masculine life, see Thomas Van Nortwick, Oedipus: The Meaning of a Masculine Life
The best English translation of Euripides’s Bacchae is by William Arrowsmith

note: Greek lyric poetry, Euripides’s Children of Herakles, and Sophocles’s Oedipus at Colonus.
title: Thomas Falkner’s The Poetics of Old Age in Greek Epic, Lyric, and Tragedy
is the best study of old age in Greek literature, with chapters devoted to Homer’s Odyssey

container-title: see Thomas Van Nortwick, Oedipus: The Meaning of a Masculine Life
title: For a fuller discussion of the ideas in this chapter about Oedipus at Colonus

The best translation of Sophocles’s Oedipus at Colonus is in Fagles 1982. The best translation of Euripides’s Children of Herakles is Henry Taylor and Robert Brooks Euripides: The Children of Herakles
